(exploding) Yeah. That’s probably true. But you know what? I have a shitload of things to regret. I regret not having a date for tomorrow’s stupid prom. I regret being too weird to make friends. I definitely regret making those shitty films with Earl. And I assume you saw the email I got today from Pitt State, when you were going through my stuff - no? You didn’t? Oh! Have a look! He opens an email on his phone and tosses it to his mom.
I'm probably gonna regret doing literally no schoolwork this year!  Blue (6/3/14) 85. GREG’S MOM (in shock) Oh my God, Greg--

I know! Admission rescinded! Due to “significant change in my academic record”! Oh well! No college! I guess I'll just be home next year! I know, it sucks. It’ll be way harder for you to go through my stuff. His mom, horrified, says nothing.

But for right now, do me a favor. And just leave me alone. I just want to sit here and regret stuff. I’m gonna think of everything I’ve ever done, and everything I haven’t done, and just regret the living shit out of it. 79 EXT./INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THAT NIGHT 79 GREG is watching his animation and his sock puppets and listening to HIS PARENTS argue through the walls.
(tearfully) The deadlines have passed, Victor! What’s he going to do next year? Is he just going to waste his year?
He is grieving, honey. You have to let him grieve.
How can you tell me to just do nothing while he ruins his life?
That’s not what I’m saying. The conversation continues as Greg watches his video.

text: Once again, GREG is eating alone under the prom banner, w now has the word “TONIGHT !!!!!"” added to it. And maybe more gratuitous quotation marks.  Blue (6/3/14) 86. And again, Madison comes to sit with him. Super: The part where I get in my second fight ever
(hesitantly) Greg? Can I ask you something? Greg gathers his things and gets up.
Nope.
It’s not what you think-- ALT: It’s not what you think. It’s about prom-- Madison touches his arm, but he shrugs it off, angrily--
(interrupting) Let me ask you something--what is this? What is up with the arm- touching? Greg is backing away from her now. She is following.

Are you just being friendly? Or is it, like, this calculated tactic? To get me to do whatever you want? Because you have to understand what it does, when a beautiful, sexy, otherwise thoughtful girl touches the arm of a scrawny pasty guy with a groundhog face. It’s an act of cruelty.
Are you done?
Yeah, I’m done with you. And I’m done with the stupid film. He backs into ILL PHIL.
But you ain’t done with me.
Oh come on.  Blue (6/3/14)
You’1l never escape me. Nobody rats me out and lives to tell about it. (MORE)
I'm back for my revenge / Stab you in the dick, pardon my French / Shove your body under a bench /

(frantic) Are you honestly gonna stab me? Fine. Go for it. You’re gonna go to jail for your entire life, but, it’s probably worth it. Stab away. Ill Phil is not prepared for this. He was hoping Greg’s reaction would be more along the lines of running away.
You lucky I ain’t got my knives. Stead you gotta fight me, punk.

Sure. I’1l fight you. Just no rapping. They square up. Onlookers excitedly gather, including a grimly snickering SCOTT MAYHEW. Neither Greg nor Phil makes a move for a long time. They actually have no idea how to fight.

(muttering rap) Break your eyeball with a Stop. fist I got clenched / Take your teeth out with a Seriously stop. wrench / Hit you with a stone from I can’t do this if you’re Stonehenge / gonna rap the whole time. Finally Ill Phil swings and Greg grabs his arm. But then doesn’t know what to do with it.
(thrashing a little) Leggo my arm.
Okay. Jesus.

Phil! Remember how he has trampled our dignity! More circling. The onlookers are becoming restless. Final Greg rushes Ill Phil and grabs him around the waist. I1l panics and grabs Greg around his waist.  81 82 Blue (6/3/14) 88. They stay like that for a while. And then, suddenly, EARL flies in and starts whooping ILL PHIL’S ass. The CROWD goes berserk. Almost immediately, the PRINCIPAL separates the fight.
The PRINCIPAL and a SECURITY GUARD are leading/dragging E GREG, and ILL PHIL to the nearest school exit.
(to Earl) I thought you were eating lunch in Mr. McCarthy's office.
He all sad. Talkin bout German music or something. I was like, dude. This is boring as hell.
The PRINCIPAL, SECURITY GUARD, GREG, EARL, and ILL PHIL emerge from the doors.

(to Greg and Earl) Two days’ suspension for fighting. Two days’ suspension for fighting. (to Ill Phil) Two days’ suspension for fighting to be added to your lifetime suspension for drug dealing. Please leave school property.
Yes sir/Awright. As they begin walking away, MADISON approaches them.
Greg.
Come to prom with me. Even Earl does not know what to say here.
Look. You were right. This whole movie situation has been really difficult for you, and I feel like it’s my fault. I want a chance to make things up to you a little bit.
Yo, you can make things up to me. (beat) You want my number?
(to Ill Phil) Ain’t nobody want your beat-ass number. You are going to die alone.
So this is a pity date?
It’s not a pity date. She smiles.

I think we'd have fun. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THAT EVENING 83 GREG is putting on his tuxedo. He is having some trouble the arms. His MOM is standing by the door. GREG’S MOM I told you you would get a date.
Yup. GREG’S MOM So, you're welcome. For the tuxedo and everything.
Thanks Mom.  84 85 Green (06/20/2014) 90. GREG’S MOM I am very unhappy about this college thing. But your father and I can wait until you're ready to talk about it.

I appreciate that. GREG’S MOM Let me help with your corsage. She does. Greg examines himself in the mirror. GREG’S MOM (CONT’D) My handsome boy, going to prom. Take lots of pictures, okay? Greg does not answer. He’s busy looking into the mirror. anxious boy in a tuxedo stares back out at him. EXT. IN FRONT OF GREG’S HOUSE - EVENING 84 GREG, holding corsage, walks stiffly into a limousine.
GREG is alone in the back of a cavernous limousine. He ha shout to reach his cheerful DRIVER.
302 Halket Street.
You got it, boss. They drive. LIMO DRIVER (CONT’D) You love this girl?
Uh. I dunno if I would go that far.
Are you kids gonna get busy on my brand-new Tuscan leather?
I think the odds are against that.  86 87 Green (06/20/2014) 91.
Ha. I’m just playing with you, man. I hope you do get some.
Thanks. It’s really gonna depend on what she wants to do.
Well. If you really love her, you got a shot. Because she’1ll know. Greg does not respond to this. LIMO DRIVER (CONT’D) She is fine, though?
I wouldn’t say that.
GREG exits the limo, holding his corsage. He is not in front of Madison’s house. He is front of the HOSPITAL. He takes a deep breath.

RACHEL is suffering from pneumonia, a complication of end stage AML. She is extremely pale and having difficulty focussing. But she smiles when GREG walks in. SUPER: Day 209 of Doomed Friendship DENISE, sitting next to her, smiles with wet eyes, gets u and hugs Greg for a very long time. Then she leaves the r
Hey.
Hey. Her voice is weak and whispery.
I know. I look amazing. Here, let me put flowers on you.
Thanks.  88 Blue (6/3/14) 92. He puts the corsage on her wrist. It is not romantic. It something else. He extracts his phone and a little projector from his poc and starts setting them up -

Before we watch this, uh... I’m really sorry it took so long to make. But the reason for that is, we couldn’t figure out how to not get it to suck. And we never did figure it out. It still sucks, and it’s not actually what I wanted to say to you. But let’s just watch it first. Okay? She nods. He turns on the projector. It projects onto the curtain. sits next to her, and they watch for a while. The film does, as advertised, suck. First, there are the TESTIMONIALS: students sitting in a classroom, saying clichéd things, or unhelpful things. So those suck. DENISE’S INTERVIEW has been jarringly edited so as not to depressing, but of course this makes it even more depress It goes without saying that this sucks. And spliced among all of these sections is a mysterious ANIMATION that is never explained and never gets enough t to develop. It’s confusing. How could that not suck? As they watch, Rachel begins to cough, weakly. Greg ignor this for a few coughs. Then he realizes that it isn’t going away.
Should I get a nurse? Rachel, nods, coughing, in pain.
GREG emerges from the room. DENISE is asleep in a chair outside. He jogs her arm. She wakes up, reads his face, a rushes into the room, stricken.  89 90 Blue (6/3/14) 93.

That was the last time I saw Rachel. She went into a coma shortly after that, and died about ten hours later. Greg flags down a passing NURSE and says something to her Irritably, she walks into Rachel’s room, shutting the doo behind her.
Yeah. I know I told you she didn’t die. But I mean... this is a story about a girl with cancer. Greg is left alone in a hospital hallway.
What did you think was going to happen?
GREG, EARL, and MR. MCCARTHY are sitting all in a row, ne the back. The forceful inner-city PRINCIPAL is speaking.

It is indeed a difficult time... for the Schenley High School family. We are mourning... a family member. But we have an unexpected and touching opportunity... to turn our thoughts to her... in a unique way. (with God’s own voice) EARL JACKSON. GREGORY GAINES. Please come to the stage. Greg's heart skips a beat. His eyes widen with terror.
From the hall, through the half-open door, DENISE watches film projected on Rachel’s curtain.
These boys made a film... that they delivered to Rachel last night.  91 92 93 Blue (6/3/14) 94.

Earl has his head deep in his hands. INT. TEACHER’S CONFERENCE ROOM - FLASHBACK, EARLIER THAT TEACHERS and the PRINCIPAL watch the film on a computer. are very moved. They are watching a sock puppet part.
And her mother has given us permission... to show you this film now.
Greg and Earl are up on stage. Cataclysm. It is, literall the stuff of nightmares.

Before we show the film... Is there anything you would like to say... to the Schenley High School family. Earl walks to the lectern. The mic is nowhere near his he The PRINCIPAL, noting this, removes the microphone and ho it to Earl’s mouth.
Naw.

You will let this audacious film speak for you. Very good. Gregory? Greg staggers to his feet. He takes the mic. He gazes out his classmates. He has nothing to say to them. But he can’t just say noth Suddenly he begins speaking.

This film sucks. And after you watch it, you’re gonna think I’m this pathetic untalented loser. But here’s the thing: I don’t care what you think about me. I’ve spent the last four years obsessing over how everyone sees me, and I just realized, I don’t care anymore. (MORE )
The only person whose opinion I care about is dead. So, whatever. He puts the mic down, then decides to pick it back up.

I’ve always wanted never to be noticed by anyone. But the best way not to be noticed is to be dead. And I don’t want to be dead. He puts the mic back. The principal, frowning, walks over reclaim the mic. Then Greg abruptly grabs it a third time.

Wait. Here’s why our film sucks. It’s not the film we should have made. Okay? Because I wasn’t even friends with Rachel before she got sick. And then she got sick and we spent all this time together, but it wasn’t enough. It just wasn’t. To make the film we should have made, we should have gotten her to tell us every single thought she has ever had. Because it’s all just lost, now. We should have had a camera on her, constantly, since the day she was born. Because her whole life, now, it’s just lost. We should have had a camera inside her head, because all of her specific thoughts and ideas and hopes and phobias and all of her impressions of the whole stupid world, they’re all about to be lost, and the film we should have made would keep her from being lost. And I know that happens to everyone. It’ll happen to everyone in this room. And it'll happen to me. But I don’t care. All that I can think about is that it happened to her. And it happened last night. And I can’t deal with it, I’1l never be able to deal with it, and this film has nothing to do with that. Nothing. (forcing back tears--semi- incoherent) It sucks. Nothing sucks more than this. It sucks.  94 95 Blue (6/3/14) 96. He puts down the mic and walks, then runs, offstage and o of the auditorium. The students are baffled. Some of them giggling, but from nervousness. Earl has his head in his hands. The lights go down.

INT. RACHEL’S LIVING ROOM - AFTERWARD 95 MOURNERS wander around Denise’s house, sitting shiva. GREG spots MADISON and SCOTT MAYHEW together holding hand talking to DENISE. Surprised and sickened, he avoids them He gazes, from afar, at the URN on the mantel that contai Rachel’s ashes. He cannot stop looking at it. It is absur him, in a way. Suddenly he has been cornered by an OLD PERSON -
I heard you made a very nice little movie about Rachel’s life.
Oh. Uh, yeah.
When will it be in theaters?  Blue (6/3/14) 97. Greg does not have the heart to set this doddering old pe straight.

Soon. Really soon. I’m sure Denise will let you know. Can you excuse me for a moment? Greg sneaks into the kitchen. He looks around for a place where he can escape all human contact. He gazes out the window, to the backyard, and sees someon EXT. RACHEL’S BACKYARD - A FEW MINUTES LATER 96 EARL has spent most of the shiva outside smoking irritabl GREG approaches him.
Look who it is.
Sorry, I haven’t been out of my room for a few days.
Yeah. I know. You smell terrible.
I can’t really smell myself.
(matter-of-factly) You smell like a homeless dude. And I heard even Pitt State ain’t takin you no more.
Yeah, well. Whatever. The backyard door opens. DENISE.
Hi boys.
Mrs. Kushner. Mrs. Kushner. I mean, Denise. Denise is holding Greg’s COLLEGE DIRECTORY.  Blue (6/3/14)
Greg, I’m supposed to give this back to you. She does. And retreats back to the doorway.
(smiling sadly) Squeak squeak.
(agreeing) (begrudgingly) Squeak. Squeak. Denise enters the house. Greg holds the college directory doing nothing. A couple of envelopes fall out. He opens one.

Dear Greg. I heard what happened with your classwork, and with Pitt State. So I wrote them a letter trying to convince them to let you back in. There’s a copy in here if you want to read it. Hopefully it works, because that would mean I have powers from beyond the grave. But you should probably send them something too. Goodbye, Greg. You’re a good friend. Although if you don’t go to college, you’re also an idiot. But you already knew that. Love, Rachel. At “goodbye,” Greg's eyes blink and go wet. He unfolds the second letter--

Dear Pittsburgh State Admissions, I am writing on behalf of someone so kind and sweet and giving that he -  Blue (6/3/14) 99. He closes it. He can’t read another word. He closes his e Earl clears his throat.
I know it’s a bad time. But I ain’t doin them films with you no more. Greg throws up his arms, like, Jesus Christ. Like it’s no already gut-wrenching enough out here.
I ain’t. I can’t. I’m done.
Why?
I'ma level with you. I never even liked makin the damn films. I like watchin crazy-ass films. But I hated makin em.
Earl, you're the talented one. You’re the one who’s supposed to do this with his life.
Oh hell no. That’s you. That ain’t me. I ain’t gonna be a broke-ass artist. (beat) Me, I want to end up like your dad.
(momentarily shocked out of misery) What?! Greg peers through the window at his DAD, who is alone in middle of the living room, scratching himself.

Listen, son. I’m just tellin you. Your dad’s around. He around all the damn time. Fact he around too much. Talkin to the cat, starin into space. But to hell with it. That’s gonna be me. Serve my kids funky-ass food, show em films with subtitles. Wear random ethnic shit. (MORE)

And I ain’t getting there by spendin all my time makin films. That is not a foundation for a comfortable life. I need a career. (not wanting to say this) I’m goin to Duquesne. Pre-law. Don’t tell nobody.
Oh. ...Earl I had no idea th--

(needing to move on) Don’t be tellin nobody. Now, you. You too weird to start a family. So you can go ahead and do your broke- ass artist thing. That’s fine. Run out of money. You can come live in my garage, with the raccoons. Me, I’m makin a comfortable life. No more films. I’m out. Silence. Earl notices GREG’S MOM watching them through the window. She hesitates. But she can’t help herself. She gestures t “smoking” to Earl, then gestures “death,” then gives him look of reproach. Earl shrugs, baffled. She sticks her head out of the window - GREG’S MOM (whispering) Earl, it’s a little inappropriate to be smoking a cigarette outside of shiva. Of someone who had cancer. Oh. Earl philosophically stubs out his cigarette.
Sorry Mrs. Gaines. She closes the window -
I’m out too. I’m not making films anymore either. I’m retired.
No, you’re not.  Blue (6/3/14) 100A. This next thing is hard to say.
Earl. If you quit, I have to quit. Earl looks Greg in the eye. Greg means it.
Listen. From now on, I'ma be your audience. And I’ma watch everything you make. Even if it’s terrible. (MORE)

And it probly will be. You probly ain’t shit without me. But that’s what friends do. They gotta watch. Even when they hate that shit. Yeah. I called you my friend. I’m your friend. Deal with it. Greg is beginning to cry again. Earl eyes him doubtfully.
And you quit, I’ma beat the hell out of you. All right?
All right.
I done it before. I'll do it again. It’s easy as hell. Because you don’t know how to fight.
All right.
Goddammit stop cryin.
I’m not c-crying.
Cryin like a bitch. Earl, after a resentful pause, puts his arm around Greg. pats Greg on the shoulder a few times.

(irritably) Feel like we're having a goddamn breakup right now. C’mon. Let’s go inside. Earl goes into the house. Greg just watches him quickly become engulfed by the adults in there. He looks over at the FIRE ESCAPE leading to Rachel’s bedr window. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM 97 GREG steps through the window and into Rachel’s room, the book under his arm, the letters in his hand. He sits on her bed. Surrounded by pillows.  Blue (6/3/14) 101A. He takes another look at the letter to him.
P.S. I’d also like for you to take some of my pillows. They’1ll want a good home where they’1l be loved. Greg picks up Francesca.
P.P.S. Not in the way you’re thinking. That’s disgusting. He gazes at the walls. Daniel Craig, Hugh Jackman.

98 Blue (6/3/14) 102. He looks down at his directory. He opens it - The inside has been CARVED OUT, intricately, into a littl landscape. He is motionless, gazing at it. It is beautiful and stran There are three small figures in it. Somehow we know they Rachel, Greg, and Earl. Rachel’s has pink hair. He runs a finger over the lip of this little fantastical place that her hands made. He gazes at her bookshelf. He pulls out a book - no carvi in there - another one - again no carving - another - This one is carved out too. A different landscape. Two figures - Rachel (the same color, but her old brown hair) one who is probably her mom. He finds more and more. A world of landscapes. Different styles, from different times in her life. Sometimes he kn who the figures are, and sometimes he doesn’t. The figure that is her is always recognizable. There is no broad narrative connecting them. They are jus scenes. Not necessarily from her life - perhaps something tangent to it. At some point we are no longer seeing the book carvings - are just watching his face, as he SEES in a way that he n has before.

Greg walks home slowly, eyes fixed on something unseeable somehow released, Rachel’s house behind him. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 98 We're back to where we started: GREG staring at a compute monitor, breathing loudly through his nose.  Blue (6/3/14) 103.

I know I might seem to you like I hate myself and everything I do. But really, I just hate everyone I’ve ever been. The person I am right now is okay. Rachel’s ashes were scattered in a park behind her house. Apparently she ran away from home once and tried to live there. It was this story her aunt told at the funeral. She was trying to become a squirrel. She thought she could turn into one by just being in the forest and wanting it really bad. I guess maybe that’s what Mr. McCarthy meant, about someone’s life continuing to unfold. It was weird to be learning something new about Rachel after she died. But somehow it was reassuring as well. The printer has just stopped printing the story we have j been told. On the back we see the words, “Somehow it was reassuring as well. FIN.” He puts it in an envelope addressed to Pittsburgh State University - Department of Admissions. And then he puts a DVD in a jewel case.
